fields.description:
Currently the merge-conflict documentation relies on the user having access to the source repository. In many cases this may not be true, and there is no (obvious) way to checkout the source branch to test.

It might be nice to have a fail-safe way to locally test an open pull-request. This may either require documentation changes, or to possibly enhance the permissions in Stash to respect the open pull-requests.
fields.summary: Update PR conflict instructions for local testing

fields.description:
As outlined in https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/179848/local-checkout-of-a-pull-request-in-stash it would be a good idea to provide a helper dialog/note/message to aid users in how to locally pull down a pull request and inspect it on a machine before merging into branch.

While the suggestion of properly pulling down the source branch is the "correct" way to do it, in practice, especially in large organizations of 200-300 people split in multiple teams, it is really a hassle to constantly re-adjust permissions to forked repos, when submitting pull requests, as any given developer has multiple pull requests open at any given time, and that would introduce significant maintenance overhead for permissions.
fields.summary: Display Pull Request "local checkout" Help

fields.description:
With "Administrator" permission I go to the global permissions page (http://<host>:7990/admin/permissions).

1. Type in the name of another user without any global permissions. 
2. Select "System Administrator" as permission.
3. Press save.

Expected result:
Stash would deny me creating a "System Administrator" since I am only a "Administrator".

Actual result:
Stash allows me to create a "System Administrator". 

Since I can create users  I'm able to create a new user give that user "System Administrator" permissions, and then log in as that user. Thus elevating my privileges.
fields.summary: Elevation of global permission from Administrator to System administrator
I like Stash, I just want to file a bug. See below

fields.description:
Lets say I have a pull request out for review.  People comment on it.  

I seriously need "next comment" / "previous comment" to be able to (as the original commiter) follow the feedback and in context of the diff.

Pretty much like FishEye does with its next comment functionality.
fields.summary: Previous and next comment keyboard shortcuts

fields.description:
Attempting to setup mail server on Stash.

Sending test email returns error requesting authentication, however exchange server allows anonymous (as used by other tools such as Jenkins).

Log file from: atlassian-stash-mail.log

subject: Stash - Test email for your SMTP configuration
org.springframework.mail.MailSendException: Failed messages: com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPSendFailedException: 530 5.7.1 Client was not authenticated

        at org.springframework.mail.javamail.JavaMailSenderImpl.doSend(JavaMailSenderImpl.java:440) ~[spring-context-support-3.2.2.RELEASE.jar:3.2.2.RELEASE]

I executed on my Oracle DB:
SELECT * FROM app_property WHERE prop_key LIKE 'mail.%';

and it returned only:
mail.host
mail.sender.address
mail.useTLS

Everytime I clean the username/password fields on the "Mail server configuration" screen and click on "Save", those credentials come back. 

Please advise.

Thanks
Jonny
fields.summary: SMTP configuration requests authentication but should allow anonymous

fields.description:
*Rating*: :) Good

{panel:title=What do you like?|borderColor=#ccc| titleBGColor=#c2ffa2|bgColor=#fff}
The Stash team, for always listening to my feedback, even when it's vague and doesn't include a solution.
{panel}

{panel:title=What needs to be improved?|borderColor=#ccc| titleBGColor=#faacad|bgColor=#fff}
I just screwed up reviewing a PR in the following way:
* Visited PR.
* Saw inline comment by the author.
* Thought about the change and wrote something.
* Was surprised by the short length of the review because I thought there was meant to be more to it.
* Clicked approve.
* REMEMBERED THERE'S A DIFF TAB.  KICKED MYSELF. (unapproved, did rest of review)

As much as it's fun to blame myself, I can't help feeling that the UI led me to this behaviour.  Aside from that subtle little Diff tab, there's really no call to action to _click_ that Diff tab.  There's no "you haven't reviewed all the files yet", there's no count of how much work there is left to do as a reviewer.  If there are comments when you get there, it's quite easy to make this mistake.  There's no "There are 2 files to review" in the Overview, which you'd think there might be.

Anyway, you see where I went wrong I imagine, and I'm sure you'll come up with an awesome solution.
{panel}
fields.summary: Better indication of how much of a pull request you have reviewed

fields.description:
In almost all companies where I worked, we had some sort of blueprint that a project in source control should adhere to.  For example, when creating a Visual Studio 2010 project, I have to

* create .gitignore to exclude Visual Studio files and folders (e.g. bin, obj)
* create folders (src, lib)
* create files (e.g. build.proj for build automation)

And so much more.  For other types of projects, be it C/C++, Java, Rails or Objective-C, the steps will be different.  However, organisations typically "standardise" the project layout for each type of project.

One way this could work is to designate a repository (let's call it "Visual Studio Solution") as a blueprint. Since its just a git repository, I can commit the standard folder structure I desire. I can also define basic permissions. Then when I create a Stash repository, I can specify "Visual Studio Solution" as the blueprint for my new repository.  The expectation would be for Stash to create a repository that is almost identical to "Visual Studio Solution".

More often than not however, I may want to customise what should happen. If my "Visual Studio Solution" has a file in the "src" folder called "MySolution.sln", I'd like to be able to rename it appropriately.  This may require that I commit a manifest file to my blueprint project. The manifest may describe variables that should be entered, files that should be renamed and so forth.  So when I create a subsequent project, Stash will ask me to enter some variables, which can be used to rename files.  In addition, I may want to replace text within files (such as build.proj with the solution).

The idea is to promote a consistent structure within the repository. It may shave an hour off the time it takes to create a repository that conforms to organisation standards.

In essence, something similar to a Confluence blueprint.
fields.summary: Support creating a project/repository from a predefined "blueprint".

fields.description:
Forks have thrown a bit of a spanner in the works of the [Unapprove Reviewers Hook|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.stash.plugin.stash-unapprove-reviewers-hook] doesn't make a lot of sense. Enabling it for a repository does not mean that updates to cross-repository pull requests will necessarily unapprove reviewers - it would need to be enabled on both the source & target repository for it to be guaranteed to work.

I'm thinking this plugin should no longer be a hook. Instead it might be best re-implemented as an event listener (listening for the PullRequestRescopedEvent - https://developer.atlassian.com/static/javadoc/stash/2.5.0/api/reference/com/atlassian/stash/event/pull/PullRequestRescopedEvent.html) with a checkbox that can be toggled on and off per repository in the Pull Request settings page, rather than as a repository hook.
fields.summary: Unapprove reviewers hook should be an event listener

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian Status – 03 January 2018|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for providing your thoughts and votes on this suggestion. We know it's been a while since this suggestion was raised and we're sorry to have kept you without a clear answer.

Your feedback has really helped us better understand the challenges you face being unable to link Jira-issues to PRs. Despite our lack of communication, this problem is actually one of those areas we plan to improve. Right now we've decided to prioritise it on our roadmap.

Thank you again for all your feedback on this suggestion and we look forward to providing you with more updates as we work on the solution.

Best,
Anton Genkin | Product Manager - Integrations
{panel}

*Original description:*
I'd like to have an option to link a JIRA issue to a pull request. The automatic linking from issues mentioned in commit messages are useful for bugs, but we usually do not include the JIRA issue key bigger features/stories because there are usually more than one commit
fields.summary: Ability to link a JIRA issue to a pull request, even when the bug id is not mentioned in any commit

fields.description: As a Stash Admin or Project Owner I want to have the ability to add users to a Stash Project & Repository without the need for the user to first login to the Stash URL given that the authentication is setup to the corporate LDAP directory
fields.summary: Add Users to Stash without need for the User to login to Stash URL
It should be possible to copy the branch name from the branch lozenge
Change location of the JIRA issue link

fields.summary: changing an internal user's password as an "Administrator" fails

fields.description: If you look at Blame in file within Stash in normal font size, all fine. But if you will Cmd+'+' to increase font size it will became to wrong height. See screenshots.
fields.summary: Blame line height is wrong on increased font size in browser

fields.description:
I can change, add, a robots.txt file easy on Jira by going to:
/opt/atlassian/jira/atlassian-jira/robots.txt
How can I do that on Stash?
If a put a robots.txt file on
/opt/atlassian/stash/atlassian-stash/robots.txt
It does not work.
Many thanks, Francisco
fields.summary: robots.txt file for STASH to stop google from crawling my site

fields.description:
Why does the Administrator account count towards the limit?
The account is not used for regular work but only for user management and general administering.
Of course I could give my own user account system administration permissions but that would
contradict the best practise of giving the least required permissions to all accounts.
I also cannot remove the "Stash User" role from the administrator account because "Stash User"
is implied by "System Administrator".
fields.summary: Stash Administrator should not count towards license user limit

fields.description: {{PermissionService#hasAnyUserPermission}} checks whether there is a current user when it shouldn't. As a result a plugin developer cannot invoke any method protected by hasAnyPermission authorization in a runWithPermission
fields.summary: PermissionService#hasAnyUserPermission incorrectly requires a context user

fields.description: I just git pulled and was forced to run git gc locally. Can this be prevented by running git gc periodically on the server, so I just clone the packfiles?
fields.summary: Avoid local git gc

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

This suggestion is a priority for the Bitbucket development team and is on our roadmap, however we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved. [Learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original request description*

We have a default set of (organizationally defined) git hooks (including commercial plugins) that we want to apply by default to all new repositories.
fields.summary: Default git hook configuration

fields.description:
Stash 2.4 allowed users to click through to the JIRA if any issues were linked via application links  but new functionality in 2.5 creates a popup screen before allowing the ability to click through. Earlier JIRA versions (4.4) aren't compatible and an error message is displayed (see [here|https://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/94895/2013-06-24_1001.png]).

Tested with:
- JIRA 4.4.4
- JIRA FishEye/Crucible/Stash 3.4.12
- Stash 2.5

fields.description:
I created a "feature" branch with one new commit ("fixed font 2").
I typed in: git push origin feature.
I created a new pull request, selecting my "feature" branch to master.
I then made two more commits on my working copy "feature" branch; "another commit" and "testing again".
I then typed in: git push origin feature.
The open pull request did not update with the two newer commits.

I tried this with a new pull request again and the same results occurred.

I opened a new Incognito window with Chrome (in case anything was getting cached client side) and revisited the pull request, still only one commit was showing not three.

I tried this with a pull request where I modified history (interactively rebased a bunch of commits into one squashed commit) and updated my feature branch, and I tried with a new pull request where I was just committing one change at a time (no history altering).

See the attached screenshots:
* The list of open pull requests.
* The list of commits on my "feature" branch after I'd made all three changes.
* The list of commits in my open pull request (this shows what I see before and after adding two new commits)
fields.summary: New commits to a branch that has an active pull request doesn't update in the PR

fields.description:
When running the first synchronisation of users from an external directory Stash reports errors:

{code}
Caused by: com.atlassian.stash.exception.NoSuchUserException: Could not find a user named user.212.
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.crowd.RiotPolice.unknownUser(RiotPolice.java:657) ~[stash-service-impl-2.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.crowd.RiotPolice.execute(RiotPolice.java:620) ~[stash-service-impl-2.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.crowd.RiotPolice.setUserAttribute(RiotPolice.java:512) ~[stash-service-impl-2.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.auth.DefaultCaptchaService.onUserCreated(DefaultCaptchaService.java:134) ~[stash-service-impl-2.6.0-SNAPSHOT.jar:na]
	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor482.invoke(Unknown Source) ~[na:na]
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) ~[na:1.7.0_05]
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:601) ~[na:1.7.0_05]
	at com.atlassian.event.internal.SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.invoke(SingleParameterMethodListenerInvoker.java:36) ~[atlassian-event-2.3.0.jar:na]
	... 32 common frames omitted
{code}

The cause is the default transaction level of MySQL being repeatable read. A temporary solution for users is to manually change the isolation level.

The isolation level can be changed by:

-  Running "SET GLOBAL TRANSACTION ISOLATION LEVEL READ COMMITTED;" on the server
- Changing the Stash JDBC configuration by editing <HOME_DIR>/stash-config.properties file and appending ",tx_isolation%3D'read-committed'" to the jdbc.url property e.g. "jdbc.url=jdbc:mysql://<server>:<port>/<db>?autoReconnect=true&characterEncoding=utf8&useUnicode=true&sessionVariables=storage_engine%3DInnoDB,tx_isolation%3D'read-committed'"

Stash needs a more permanent solution to deal with this bug.
fields.summary: Synchronising a directory fails on MySQL
I'd like to be able to link to other Stash content from a PR

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

From [Bitbucket Server and Data Center 7.2|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-2-release-notes-1001823759.html] we prioritize the exact branch name matches.

When searching for a branch by its name, you will now see it first in the list of results if it matches the exact name or prefix you typed in. No more scrolling through an alphabetized list of branch results that contain the text.

Cheers,
 Imran Khan
 Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original description:*

It would be very convenient if Stash would allow users to select branches by typing their exact name (for example, "master"). Currently, Stash just brings up a list of all branches that contain the typed text and one must scroll through the list to choose the right one.

We have a fairly large repository, and a large number of branches contain the word 'master'. This requires scrolling down through pages of imperfect matches until reaching the true "master" branch. It's even trickier due to the fact that the branches don't appear to be sorted in alphabetical order by letter.

Would it be possible to modify the branch selection in Stash so a user could simply type a branch name like 'master'. hit enter, and have stash select the exact match (if one exists?)
fields.summary: Allow user to select branch by typing exact branch name

fields.description:
We have Stash connected to Crowd, where some users are stored and inactive, that have left the organisation. unforntunatley these users are known ins stash and can be set as reviewer in Pull-Requests.

These users won´t be available ever and this can lead to long waiting times until a dev gets to the point that the user is inactive.
another problem is, that the list of suggested reviewers contains inactive users, potentially grown number.

solution drafts:

- Allow only licensed and active users to be reviewer

fields.description:
Add a possibility to group repositories into a Repository Group.
And all repositories are viewed as one if you look at it but the top level is the different repositories.
This makes everything easier if you have a multi repository project.
Or if you want to group repositories by customer or internal customer.

fields.description:
Generally speaking, plugin developers are finding the cancelable {{xxxxRequestedEvents}} an extremely useful way to make Stash better suit their workflow and project constraints. 

It would be useful to have a set of [CancelableEvent|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/javadoc/stash/2.5.0/api/reference/com/atlassian/stash/event/CancelableEvent.html] subclasses that offer similar hooks into project, repository and global permission granting and revocation so that plugin developers can enforce custom security policies.

e.g. {{ProjectPermissionGrantRequestedEvent}}, {{GlobalPermissionRevocationRequestedEvent}}, etc.
fields.summary: Cancelable Permission Grant/Revoke events

With Stash 2.5.0, if you create an application link with JIRA (2.5.11 for instance), then "Application 'Your Company JIRA' seems to be offline. Click here to Relocate." is displayed in the Configure Application Link GUI. Then in the STASH logs there is "signature_invalid" or "BAD_SIGNATURE".

fields.description:
The mouseover tooltip on the "Approve" button always displays the text "Approve this pull request (type 'a')" even if the pull request is approved. This sometimes leads to accidentaly unapproved pull-requests.

Short video clip illustrating this situation attached to this ticket (and also available directly from http://screencast.com/t/pnA2FKRrls55)
fields.summary: Mouseover tooltip on "Approve" button always tells user to "Approve this pull request"

fields.description:
When viewing the auto-generated commit message in Stash for a merge that came about from a Pull Request, I'd like to be able to easily return to the Pull Request that instigated that merge.

The following screenshot gives one suggestion, where the text is hot-linkified to the Pull Request

!Selection_629.png!

However, another suggestion is Stash simply indexes the commit sha against pull requests and adds a link along the right side, similar to links to JIRA tickets.
fields.summary: Hotlink to pull requests mentioned in the commit message from a merge

fields.description:
When opening a JIRA issue link from the commit pages, the text is displayed however all images and 'View in JIRA' urls are incorrect as they are missing the port number. e.g. https:\\servername/browse/XXX-000 instead of https:\\servername:8443/browse/XXX-000

Both Jira and Stash are running over HTTPS and because of JIRA permissions outgoing authentication in stash is basic authentication

The link to the JIRA issue from the commits page appears to be correct, it is the pop up that is incorrect
fields.summary: Jira URLS are not correct

fields.description:
Sometimes users need to read conclusions about some commit. They need to find discussion in pull request where such commit was reviewed.

Now one solution, is run Source Tree, find sha1 in Tree View, see into commit message, maybe it will contains 'Merge Pull Request #1234' and then find Pull Request by number.

Or found commit via `git branch -r --contains`, found first branch where was such commit. Found tip of branch, and then perform `git ls-remote | grep 'pull-request' | grep <tip of branch>`

All these ways are hard. Will be nice to have simple finder directly in Stash.
fields.summary: Easy to find pull request from blame/commit view

fields.description:
Almost all other Atlassian applications has the option to change the location of their logs. 
It would be really helpful to have a similar feature in Stash whereby the logs location can be set/configured via a system property.
fields.summary: Have a configurable system property to change Stash logs location

fields.description:
The setup:
1) Bamboo is set to auto-detect Git branches and clone the build plan.
2) Branches are set to auto-merge 'master' into the feature branch.
3) Stash is setup to require at least 1 successful build before a Pull Request merge is allowed.

The problem:
1 - Developer pushes changes to their branch ("Feature B")
2 - Bamboo kicks off a build.  First it auto-merges changes from 'master' into branch "Feature B".
3 - Tests run.  Build completes successfully and is green.  Bamboo pushes the merge back on to "Feature B" branch.
4 - From Stash, create a Pull Request to merge "Feature B" into "master"
5 - "Merge" button is disabled with a warning that "You need a minimum of one successful build before this pull request can be merged."
6 - From Bamboo, you now need to run another (redundant) build in order to activate the "Merge" button in the pull request.

It seems that Bamboo pushing the auto-merge throws Stash off and makes it think there wasn't a green build since the last commit.

It's very annoying to have to trigger a redundant build if an auto-merge takes place just to get the 'merge' button activated.
fields.summary: "Minimum successful builds" will block the merge of a Pull Request if Bamboo auto-merges code.

fields.description:
If you run git merge with rename analysis, (define 'merge.renameLimit'), then you get follow conflict:
{code}
<<<<<<< HEAD:src/a.txt
aaaaa
=======
bbbbb
>>>>>>> origin/my_branch:src/b.txt
{code}
But the `Conflict` object will contains only `path` field initialized, and not `srcPath`. This will deny developer to understand Conflict path in source branch.
fields.summary: Parse conflict markers to create valid Conflict object with correct srcPath

fields.description:
*Problem:* it's not possible to specify empty credentials, because they are automatically set and cannot be removed.
As a result, we're unable to send emails.

*Scenario:*
One of our customers doesn't need any credentials and not being able to unset them leads to this issue: [STASH-3482|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-3482]

However, if we try to send a test email with empty credentials (as mentioned in this comment related to Jira: [JRA-27623|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-27623?focusedCommentId=483858&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-483858]) that test email is correctly sent.
fields.summary: SMTP configuration should allow empty credentials

fields.description:
When users go to our JIRA project they don't know who is an administrator of the project (which they often want to know because they want to create a new repo).

Stash should show the project intro (like a README.md in repos) for the entire project where we could add info about the project admins/leads, and any other important project-wide info.
fields.summary: Add project intro text

fields.description:
We use feature branches that we would like to clean up after merging. At the same time we don't want to allow branch deletes on our canonical release/development branches. Ideally there would be an option in Stash to deny branch deletes based on a glob patter.

I know there is an option to delete branches when merging a PR but we often use feature branches without PRs.
fields.summary: Add option to deny branch deletion based on shell glob

fields.description:
From the web interface, if I try to see / find any private  repositories that have been shared to me, that is very difficult.  It basically required me to manually edit the url to go to a particular user and then I could see the repository there.

NEW FEATURE:
Browsing/managing personal repositories should be easier:
- Admins should be able to easily detect personal repos, including orphaned ones: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-7265
- As I Stash user, it'd be easier to browse to personal repos that have been shared with me using the UI. It basically requires users to know which repos they have access to and you have to manually edit the url to go to a particular user and then I could see the repository there.
- As an Admin, it'd be good if you could set quota on how much disk a user can take up: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/STASH-2663
fields.summary: Provide easier access to personal repositories

Bitbucket  UI to import from GIThub in one click (See [this|http://blog.bitbucket.org/2013/04/02/finnovation-brings-you-a-heap-of-new-features/] and [this|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Import+code+from+an+existing+project#Importcodefromanexistingproject-Importfromahostingsiteorprojectusingtheimporter])

Our current process involves a lot of work:

For people migrating from Bitbucket to Stash, there should be a way to import the users and groups from Bitbucket as well as the Pull Requests and Commit Comments.

fields.description:
I upgraded our test install to 2.5.0, and I created acouple dummy users - AdminAmy and ProjectPaul, and went through a few scenarios with them. It appears that anyone project create permissions down to repo admin can toggle and untoggle the "make public" checkbox. Can there be a system setting to gray that box out unless you're a system administrator? As it is, we have been encourage by Atlassian to disseminate project create/admin privs as much as possible (it's in your own documentation) but that level of access allows you to make all repos in a project or individual repos public, which isn't a small think here. We have IP concerns in our repositories so sharing them publicly is a IP & security risk for us. 

A secondary improvement request would be to see a list of all public repos in the system admin screens, so we don't have to click in and out of each project to look to see what has been exposed.
fields.summary: Restrict granting of public access to global administrators

fields.description:
I noticed the new "Secure SSL" option under "Advanced Settings" while configuring "Delegated LDAP Authentication". I tried clearing the check box and testing, but the LDAP connection still fails because the SSL cert is not valid.
I can work around the problem by importing the key into the keystore, but I'd be really happy if this option actually worked. :) Then I wouldn't have to update the LDAP configuration every year when the keys change... :p
fields.summary: Advanced setting to ignore LDAP SSL certificate errors while configuring Delgated LDAP Authentication doesn't work

fields.description:
If a pull request (A) is being reviewed and there are no merge conflicts, and then another pull request (B) is approved and merged and this results in a new merge conflict in A, send email to the originator of the A pull request about the newly created merge conflict.

Currently you either have to go to the webpage and notice the merge conflict yourself, or someone else in the group has to notice it and notify you.
fields.summary: Send email when new merge conflict appears in pull request as other requests are merged.

if it is possible to integrate this application navigator to stash it would be relly great. Thanks.

fields.description:
We need to perform merges with:
{code}
git -c merge.renameLimit=32765 merge -s recursive -X patience --no-ff --log
{code}
If Stash will allo to specify merge command within Pull Request settings it will be amazing. If only in stash-config.properties it will be also great.

We need this for large repository (many-many files, over 2GB). Git stop rename analyses if you run git merge without any settings from above.

The main reason why we need this. We get dozen conflicts in moved files. But Stash make automerge with DELETED conflict only, it did not understand renames correctly.
fields.summary: Ability to define Auto merge command in stash-config.properties

fields.description:
Through branch permissions, we allow our developers to only create/update specific branches in the repository and lock everything else.

However, the same permissions we define for branches also affects tags, therefore developers are unable to push tags to Stash in a free form (given the branch permission constraints).

My suggestion/request is to have separate permissions for tags or (at least for a start) have a flag in the repository settings which just allows people to push tags freely and not validate these against the branch permissions.
fields.summary: Allow defining separate permissions for tags and branches

fields.description:
Scenario:

A project  called "Company" has one repository called "Website". This repository has two branches, "master" and "develop".

All developers in the company have write access to the "Company" project, but branch permissions dictates that they cannot push directly to "master" or "develop". They must send pull requests which are then merged by the integrators team.

Maria creates a fork of "Website", so she has the "Maria/Website" repository. She creates a feature branch in her repository, do the work, then submits a pull request from "Maria/Website/feature-branch" to "Company/Website/develop".

A couple of developers are selected to review her pull request, they all have write access to the "Company" project and all of its repositories, but they only have read access to Maria's fork.

*The problem*: The only action that the developers can do is "Approve". They cannot "Decline" that pull request, unless Maria give's them write access to the fork.

This doesn't make sense and is not consistent with the behavior we have without forks.

If Maria had done all that in a branch of "Website" instead of a fork, and then submitted a pull request, all developers would be able to approve or decline it.
fields.summary: Declining a pull request from a fork requires write access to the fork

fields.description: For our deployment systems/targets we use simply git read only accounts to pull changes in a git repository. Currently you need to create a stash-user for that which increase your license user count. IMHO there should be an option to allow git repository access for non-stash-users, so that these users can't login in stash but pull changes from defined repositories.
fields.summary: Unlicensed git read only user

fields.description:
Configuration items that need to be configured by the administrator are mixed with configuration items that are not meant to be end user configurable.

The biggest pain point here is bin/setenv.sh (which should be split in two and put in the conf directory as it's actually a configuration file) as STASH_HOME and JVM_XXX_MEMORY need to be set to run.

Everything above "In general don't make changes below here" should be in a separate file so that we can create templates for our configuration management systems (such as Puppet) and not have to update the template every time we upgrade Stash due to changes by Atlassian.
fields.summary: User configuration and atlassian configuration should be separate

fields.description:
One of the things I like very much about gitolite is the easy command line ssh access, for example:

git clone git@git.company.com:reponame

Given the project/repo hierarchy of Stash, I imagine the simplest you could get would be:

git clone git@git.company.com:project/reponame

Gitolite (https://github.com/sitaramc/gitolite) supports this by having a separate git ssh user, and doing some very neat stuff in authorized_keys that  links a given ssh key passed for the git user to a specific set of authorizations controlled by gitolite.

Now that Stash has private repositories and public sign up, this is the last thing holding me back from migrating from gitolite without hesitation.
fields.summary: Add support for SSH access via sshd

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce:
h4.SQL Server
# Create a database 'atlassian'
# Create a schema name 'stash' in the database
# Create a user 'stash' with the default schema 'stash'
# Connect Stash server with SQL server database 'atlassian'

All the tables are created in the default schema 'dbo' except for AO tables created in schema 'stash'
h4.Oracle
# Create a database user 'stash'
# Grant all the permission to the user 'stash' on the schema 'stash'
# Grant another access permission to the user 'stash' on the schema 'crowd' (schema 'crowd' has been used by Crowd application)
# Migrate Stash database from HSQLDB to Oracle through the UI
It will fail with the following error:
{noformat}
2014-02-07 12:09:03,235 ERROR [http-bio-7990-exec-7] 728x27x0 jv58e6 10.123.16.180 "POST /setup HTTP/1.1" c.a.s.i.db.DefaultDatabaseManager Failed to obtain session factory
org.springframework.beans.factory.BeanCreationException: Error creating bean with name 'sessionFactoryPrototype' defined in class path resource [stash-context.xml]: Invocation of init method failed; nested exception is org.hibernate.HibernateException: Missing column: is_allow_all in CROWD.CWD_APP_DIR_MAPPING
	at org.springframework.beans.factory.support.AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.initializeBean(AbstractAutowireCapableBeanFactory.java:1512) ~[spring-beans-3.2.5.RELEASE.jar:3.2.5.RELEASE]
	at org.springframework.context.support.AbstractApplicationContext.getBean(AbstractApplicationContext.java:1129) ~[spring-context-3.2.5.RELEASE.jar:3.2.5.RELEASE]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.db.DefaultDatabaseManager.createSessionFactory(DefaultDatabaseManager.java:337) [stash-service-impl-2.10.1.jar:na]
	at com.atlassian.stash.internal.db.DefaultDatabaseManager.prepareDatabase(DefaultDatabaseManager.java:158) [stash-service-impl-2.10.1.jar:na]
{noformat}
it seems that Stash somehow try to use the schema 'crowd' cause the database user 'stash' have access permission to it.
fields.summary: Add schema support when connecting Stash to SQL Server, PostgreSQL and Oracle

fields.description:
I'm usually sign-off my commits, but when looking on the 'commits' overview it's kind of annoying that the signed-off line is appended to the commit-msg-preview.

fields.description:
If paged-table has setting to show only one row at page. Something like very-very heavy row calculations and you need to show rows one step by one step.

When second row will try to fetch data, it make it quickly right after previous one row displayed. It will perform second AJAX request and show spinner, but previous setTimeout turn off it right after the AJAX request performed.
fields.summary: PagedTable JS component spinner hiding race conditions

fields.description:
*Update : April 2019*

Bitbucket Server and Data Center release 5.6 includes some changes to make it easier to find your own personal forks, as well as any other forks of a repository. 


*Original request description*

It would be nice if when you went to view a repo's page you could in some way get a list of all the forks off that repo. Would this a be a feature you would be willing to add to Stash?
fields.summary: Show a list of forks off of a repo

fields.description:
h1. Steps
 * Given a user with ssh key set in profile
 * Create a new project
 * Create a bare repository
 * View new repository

h2. Observed

The repository provides very useful help text for new users to get setup and working, however, the documents indicate to use the https protocol rather than the ssh urls, eg

{noformat}git clone https://toby@stash/scm/tst/my-repo.git{noformat}

h2. Impact

 * Users will be asked for credentials each time they perform an online action
 * self-signed certificates on stash will cause git to throw out errors
 * the http protocol is inefficient for both client and server

h1. Recommendation

Update the text on the page depending on if the user has a ssh key defined, and if they do not, perhaps provide a link to let them add one.
fields.summary: Show ssh urls on bare repository help text when user has ssh keys present

fields.description:
Stash will add all previous commit messages into a merge commit message, this results in duplicate time entries in JIRA when using FishEye Smart Commits.

Steps to reproduce:
* Create a branch and commit a change with "KEY-123 #time 10m"
* Create a pull request for the branch and merge it
* The merge commit that Stash creates will contain "KEY-123 #time 10m" again
* 20 minutes will be logged against issue KEY-123

Expected behaviour:
* Only 10 minutes should be logged against KEY-123

Suggested fix:
* Remove all previous commit message from the merge commit message - isn't this what `git log` is for?
fields.summary: Merge commit message produces duplicate time entries

fields.description:
As a repository administrator it can be hard to know who has access to your repository and what level of access, because implicit project permissions (and global permissions) are only visible in other parts of the Stash interface (the respective project and global permission pages). Furthermore, the repository admin may not have access to these pages to discover this information. It would be nice if the implicit permissions were displayed somehow on the repository permissions page.

Originally split from STASH-3508
{quote}
In general, having both project and repo permissions is confusing because I have to look at two screens to understand what is going on. But, it's also very useful to be able to set defaults.

You could solve this very easily by making implicit project permissions show up automatically on the repo permission list. Perhaps they could be faded to indicate that these permissions are inherited, and they wouldn't have an 'x' button to remove them.

If the UI did this, I could look at the repo screen and see exactly who has access to the repo and who does not. Also, a repo admin could very easily check and uncheck boxes on the repo screen, expanding or restricting project permissions as he/she chooses.

This is more powerful than what the current UI allows, and I think it's more intuitive. There is one simple rule to remember: look at the repo screen to see who can access your repo.

One final corner case: if a project permission is deleted, then the corresponding repo permission should go away if it still corresponds to the default. If the repo admin has restricted or expanded it, the explicit change should stay on the repo to reflect the repo admin's intent.
{quote}

h3. Workaround
The not-aggregated information can be retrieve by using the Bitbucket Server [REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.4.1/bitbucket-rest.html]:
- The permissions set at +global level+ can be accessed with [this call|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.4.1/bitbucket-rest.html#idp2293648]
- The permissions set at +project level+ can be retrieved with [this call|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.4.1/bitbucket-rest.html#idp2931552]
- For the permissions at +repositories level+ use [this one|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.4.1/bitbucket-rest.html#idp3118704].
fields.summary: Display implicit Project/Global permissions on repository permissions page
Better describe how repository permissions work in conjunction with project permissions

fields.description:
We configured a wait_timeout of 90 seconds and an interactive_timeout of 120 seconds in the MySQL server. Non of the options mentioned at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Connection+Timeout+with+MySQL+Database help to prevent that the Stash MySQL connections get closed after 90 seconds. "db.pool.idle.maxAge=1" has no effect in the latest Stash version 2.4.1 and 2.4.2.

The only solution is to host Stash on a MySQL server with wait_timeout=0.
fields.summary: Connection Timeout with MySQL Database

fields.description:

Absolute URLs should use HTTPS to include foreign sources.
fields.summary: Gravatar image breaks SSL connection
